depth_guidance.deep: Exhaustive detection: every detectable tactic instance mapped with comprehensive evidence, including borderline cases with explicit reasoning for inclusion/exclusion, comparison of the same tactic across multiple work-pairs, and assessment of the author's tactical sophistication (do tactics become more subtle over time?)
depth_guidance.standard: Systematic detection across all significant position shifts, with full vocabulary/framing/methodological evidence chains, confidence ratings, and severity assessments for each instance
depth_guidance.surface: Detect the 3-5 most prominent tactic instances with brief evidence

analytical_dimensions.description: Identifying specific tactic instances with full evidence chains. Each detection specifies: which tactic from the taxonomy, the source work (earlier position with quotes), the target work (current position with quotes), vocabulary evidence (how word choice supports the detection), framing evidence (how presentation changes support the detection), methodological evidence (how method continuity or change supports the detection), confidence level, and severity. The detection must be VERIFIABLE -- a reader given the evidence should be able to confirm or dispute the finding.
probing_questions: For each pair of works, what position shifts occurred and how were they managed?
Where has tentative language been replaced by definitive language without new evidence (strategic escalation)?
Where has the author contradicted a prior position without acknowledging the contradiction (silent revision)?
Where are concepts reappearing under new names (vocabulary laundering) or in new frameworks (framework migration)?
Where are inconvenient prior commitments simply absent from the discussion (strategic amnesia)?
Where is the author using past credibility to support current speculation (authority bootstrapping)?
What vocabulary, framing, and methodological evidence supports each detection?

depth_guidance.deep: Comprehensive pattern analysis: full distribution with statistical characterization, all tactic clusters mapped with functional analysis (what each cluster achieves), comparison of the author's tactic profile with common profiles in their field, assessment of whether the tactic repertoire is typical or distinctive, and narrative synthesis of what the pattern reveals about the author's relationship with their own intellectual history
depth_guidance.standard: Full distribution analysis, cluster identification with explanation of how clustered tactics reinforce each other, and characterization of the author's overall management style
depth_guidance.surface: Note the most frequent tactic and any obvious clusters

analytical_dimensions.description: Moving beyond individual detections to see the patterns. Which tactic does the author use most frequently? Which tactics cluster together (e.g., narrative bootstrapping + escalation, selective continuity + retroactive framing)? What does the overall tactic distribution reveal about the author's intellectual management style? Some authors are primarily escalators (always amplifying), others are primarily revisers (always changing quietly), and others are primarily narrators (always constructing coherence stories). The pattern is the fingerprint.
probing_questions: What is the most frequently used tactic type, and what does that reveal?
What is the distribution across all 10 tactic types?
Which tactics cluster together -- appear in the same passages or serve the same strategic purpose?
What does the overall pattern reveal about the author's intellectual management style?
Is there a dominant mode: escalation, revision, narration, or amnesia?

depth_guidance.deep: Full diachronic analysis: tactic usage tracked across all career periods, correlation with intellectual crisis points, sophistication trajectory, comparison of early vs late tactical repertoire, and assessment of whether the author has become more or less self-aware about their own tactics
depth_guidance.standard: Map tactic usage by career period, identify inflection points, and assess whether tactical sophistication increases over time
depth_guidance.surface: Note any obvious shifts in tactic usage between early and late career

analytical_dimensions.description: How the author's tactical repertoire changes over time. Do early works show simpler tactics (direct revision) while later works show more sophisticated ones (complexity shielding, legacy management)? Are there periods of intense tactical activity -- perhaps corresponding to major intellectual shifts? Does the author develop new tactics as their career progresses, or rely on the same repertoire throughout? Tactic evolution is itself a kind of intellectual evolution, and tracking it reveals how the author's self-management capacity develops.
probing_questions: How does the tactic repertoire change across the author's career?
Do tactics become more sophisticated over time?
Are there periods of intense tactical activity corresponding to intellectual crises?
Does the author develop new tactics or rely on the same ones throughout?
Is there a relationship between the magnitude of position change and the sophistication of tactics used to manage it?

depth_guidance.deep: Full effectiveness analysis: each instance rated for execution quality, audience-relative effectiveness, transparency to different reader types, comparison of intended vs actual effect, and assessment of the author's overall tactical skill level
depth_guidance.standard: Effectiveness rating for each detected tactic instance, with analysis of what makes some more effective than others and how audience/context affects success
depth_guidance.surface: Brief assessment of effectiveness for the most prominent tactics

analytical_dimensions.description: How well does each tactic actually work? A silent revision may go unnoticed by most readers but be transparent to specialists. A strategic escalation may be effective in popular writing but fail in peer review. Vocabulary laundering may succeed when the author has moved to a new audience but fail when the same readers follow both old and new work. Effectiveness depends on audience, context, and the quality of execution. Some authors are gifted tacticians; others are clumsy and transparent.
probing_questions: For each detected tactic, how likely is it to succeed with the intended audience?
Are there tactics that work well in one context but fail in another?
Does the author execute tactics skillfully or clumsily?
Have any of the author's tactics been publicly called out by critics?
What makes certain tactic instances more effective than others?

depth_guidance.deep: Complete taxonomic analysis: every category assessed for fit, all hybrids and novel tactics documented with proposed classifications, taxonomy coverage analysis, and reflexive assessment of whether this author's practice reveals limitations in the taxonomy that should be addressed
depth_guidance.standard: Full taxonomy instantiation with notes on any hybrids, gaps, and potential extensions
depth_guidance.surface: List which taxonomy categories are present and absent

analytical_dimensions.description: The complete classification system for all detected tactics. While the 10 core types provide the initial framework, real intellectual behavior sometimes produces hybrid tactics, novel tactics that don't fit the taxonomy, or variants that refine the categories. This dimension captures the full taxonomy as instantiated in this author's work, including any extensions or modifications needed to accommodate what was actually found.
probing_questions: Do all detected tactics fit cleanly into the 10 core types?
Are there hybrid tactics -- combinations of two or more types?
Are there novel tactics this author employs that the taxonomy doesn't capture?
Which taxonomy categories are instantiated and which are absent?
Does this author's tactical repertoire suggest refinements to the taxonomy itself?

depth_scaling.deep: Exhaustive detection including borderline cases with explicit inclusion/exclusion reasoning, tracking of the same tactic across multiple work-pairs, micro-analysis of tactical execution quality, and assessment of whether tactics become more sophisticated over the author's career
depth_scaling.standard: Systematic detection across all significant position shifts with full three-domain evidence chains (vocabulary, framing, methodology), confidence ratings, and severity assessments for each instance
depth_scaling.surface: 3-5 most prominent tactic instances identified with brief evidence quotes from source and target works

capabilities.description: Identify specific tactic instances with verifiable evidence chains across vocabulary, framing, and methodology
capabilities.extended_description:
This capability performs the foundational work of identifying specific instances where an author manages the relationship between their prior and current positions using one of the ten tactical repertoires. Drawing on Goffman's dramaturgical sociology, it treats each tactic instance as a moment of intellectual face-work—where the author performs coherence while navigating actual discontinuity. The detection must be verifiable: for each instance, it establishes an evidence chain across three domains (vocabulary, framing, methodology), locates the source position in earlier work and target position in current work, and assesses confidence and severity. This is not impressionistic criticism but forensic analysis—building cases that can be confirmed or disputed by returning to the texts.

This capability feeds all others in the engine: without specific tactic detections, there can be no pattern analysis, no evolution tracking, no effectiveness assessment. It transforms the vague sense that "the author changed their mind" into a structured catalog of how that change was managed rhetorically. The capability must distinguish between legitimate intellectual development (acknowledged, justified) and tactical management (unacknowledged, compensatory). A naive version simply spots contradictions; a sophisticated version recognizes that the same contradiction can be managed through multiple tactics simultaneously (e.g., vocabulary laundering + strategic amnesia), understands that absence of acknowledgment is itself evidence, and tracks how methodological continuity can mask conceptual migration.
indicators: An author makes a strong claim without citation to their own prior tentative work on the same topic
Key terms from earlier work are absent when discussing what appears to be the same concept under a new name
Methodological framing shifts (e.g., from empirical to theoretical) without explicit justification for the change
The author cites their earlier work selectively, omitting passages that would contradict current position
Hedging language in earlier work ('might', 'could', 'tentatively') replaced by definitive language ('is', 'demonstrates', 'establishes') without new evidence

intellectual_grounding.method: Following Goffman's analysis of self-presentation, this capability treats intellectual work as a performance requiring consistency maintenance. It identifies the 'front stage' (public position) versus 'back stage' (actual position shift) discrepancies, examining the dramaturgical techniques authors use to manage potentially discrediting information about their intellectual past.

depth_scaling.deep: Comprehensive pattern analysis with statistical characterization of distribution, all tactic clusters mapped with functional analysis, comparison to field-typical profiles, assessment of repertoire distinctiveness, and narrative synthesis of what the pattern reveals about the author's relationship with their intellectual history
depth_scaling.standard: Full distribution analysis across all tactic types, identification of functional clusters with explanation of how they reinforce each other, and characterization of overall management style with comparison to common profiles
depth_scaling.surface: Most frequent tactic identified with note of any obvious clustering (e.g., 'primarily uses strategic escalation, often combined with authority bootstrapping')

capabilities.description: Identify the distribution, clustering, and overall profile of the author's tactical repertoire
capabilities.extended_description:
This capability moves from individual tactical moments to the author's characteristic repertoire—the distinctive profile of how they manage intellectual change. Following Bourdieu's field theory, it recognizes that each author develops a habitus of self-management, a set of dispositions that generate patterned tactical responses to intellectual discontinuity. The analysis produces a distribution across the ten tactic types, identifies which tactics cluster together (revealing strategic combinations), and characterizes the author's overall management style. Some authors are primarily escalators (always amplifying modest claims), others are revisers (quietly changing without acknowledgment), still others are narrators (constructing coherent developmental stories). The pattern is the fingerprint—it reveals not just what an author does, but their characteristic mode of handling the relationship with their own past.

This capability depends on detect_tactics for raw material but transforms it into a higher-order portrait. It enables downstream assessment of whether an author's tactical repertoire is typical for their field or distinctive, whether it becomes more sophisticated over time, and how it relates to their position in intellectual space. A naive version simply counts tactic frequencies; a sophisticated version recognizes that tactics form functional clusters (framework migration + vocabulary laundering work together to relocate a concept), identifies dominant modes that reveal intellectual temperament, and assesses whether the repertoire shows strategic coherence or opportunistic improvisation.
indicators: The same tactic type appears across multiple work-pairs separated by years
Certain tactics consistently appear together in the same passages or serving the same shift
One tactic type dominates the frequency distribution (>40% of instances)
Tactical combinations show functional coherence (e.g., amnesia about inconvenient claims + escalation of convenient ones)
The overall pattern resembles known profiles (the escalator, the quiet reviser, the narrative constructor)

intellectual_grounding.method: Applying Bourdieu's concept of habitus to intellectual practice, this capability treats tactic patterns as embodied dispositions—not conscious strategies but internalized schemes of intellectual self-management. It examines how repeated tactical choices constitute a durable orientation toward one's own intellectual history, shaped by field position and accumulated cultural capital.

depth_scaling.deep: Full diachronic analysis tracking tactic usage across all career periods, correlation with intellectual crisis points and major position shifts, sophistication trajectory assessment, comparison of early versus late tactical repertoire, and evaluation of whether the author has become more or less self-aware about their own tactical practices
depth_scaling.standard: Tactic usage mapped by career period (early/middle/late), inflection points identified, and assessment of whether tactical sophistication trajectory is increasing, stable, or decreasing
depth_scaling.surface: Note of any obvious shifts between early and late career (e.g., 'later works use more sophisticated complexity shielding')

capabilities.description: Track how the author's tactical repertoire changes across career stages
capabilities.extended_description:
This capability tracks the diachronic development of the author's tactical repertoire across career stages, revealing how their self-management capacity evolves. Drawing on Lakatos's methodology of research programmes, it recognizes that intellectual evolution involves not just changing ideas but changing meta-level strategies for managing change. Early-career tactics may be crude (direct contradiction without acknowledgment), while mature tactics become sophisticated (complexity shielding that buries contradictions in technical apparatus). Periods of intense tactical activity often correspond to paradigm shifts within the author's own work—moments when the relationship between past and present becomes most strained. Tracking this evolution reveals whether an author develops greater tactical sophistication, maintains a stable repertoire, or becomes more transparent and self-aware about their own changes.

This capability requires tactic_detection as input and tactic_patterns for comparative analysis across periods. It enables assessment of whether tactical sophistication correlates with intellectual crisis points, whether the author becomes more or less transparent over time, and whether new tactics emerge or old ones persist throughout the career. A naive version simply chronologically orders tactic instances; a sophisticated version identifies inflection points where repertoire shifts, correlates tactical intensity with intellectual crisis, assesses whether sophistication increases (suggesting strategic learning) or remains stable (suggesting dispositional consistency), and evaluates whether late-career work shows more self-awareness about intellectual management.
indicators: Early works show simple tactics (silent revision, strategic amnesia) while later works show complex ones (complexity shielding, legacy management)
A cluster of multiple tactic types appears around a specific career inflection point or major work
The same tactic type is executed more skillfully in later works than earlier ones
New tactics appear in the repertoire that were absent in early career
Late-career works explicitly acknowledge and justify position changes that earlier works managed tacitly

intellectual_grounding.method: Following Lakatos's analysis of how research programmes evolve through protective belt modifications, this capability treats tactic evolution as meta-level programme management. It examines how authors develop increasingly sophisticated protective mechanisms around their core commitments, tracking whether the tactical repertoire shows progressive (increasingly sophisticated) or degenerating (increasingly crude or desperate) evolution.

depth_scaling.deep: Full effectiveness analysis for every instance with ratings for execution quality, audience-relative success, transparency to different reader types (specialists/generalists), comparison of intended versus actual effect, documentation of any public callouts, and overall assessment of whether the author is a skilled or clumsy tactician
depth_scaling.standard: Effectiveness rating for each detected tactic instance, analysis of what makes some more effective than others (execution, audience, context), and assessment of the author's overall tactical skill level
depth_scaling.surface: Brief effectiveness assessment for the 3-5 most prominent tactics (e.g., 'likely to succeed with general readers but transparent to specialists')

capabilities.description: Evaluate how well each tactic works given audience, context, and execution quality
capabilities.extended_description:
This capability evaluates how well each tactic actually works in context—whether it successfully manages the impression of coherence or fails transparently. Effectiveness depends on multiple factors: audience sophistication (specialists may detect silent revisions that generalists miss), context of use (popular writing versus peer review), and execution quality (skilled versus clumsy deployment). Following Goffman's attention to performance success conditions, this capability assesses whether the face-work succeeds or fails, whether the impression management convinces its intended audience. Some authors are gifted tacticians whose framework migrations seem natural and justified; others are transparent and awkward, producing tactics that call attention to the very discontinuities they attempt to mask. Effectiveness also varies by tactic type: vocabulary laundering may work well when changing audiences but fail when the same readers follow both old and new work.

This capability depends on tactic_detection for specific instances but adds evaluative assessment of success. It enables identification of which tactics work best for this author, which contexts make tactics more or less effective, and whether the author's overall tactical skill level is high or low. A naive version assumes all detected tactics fail ("caught in contradiction"); a sophisticated version recognizes that many tactics succeed with most readers, evaluates effectiveness relative to intended audience and context, distinguishes execution quality from tactical choice, and identifies cases where tactics have been publicly called out versus cases where they operate successfully below critical radar.
indicators: Critical reviews or peer responses explicitly identify a tactic (e.g., 'Smith contradicts their earlier work without acknowledgment')
The same tactic works in popular writing but fails in specialist contexts, or vice versa
Execution shows telltale signs of clumsiness (awkward phrasing, over-emphasis, defensive hedging)
Evidence that different reader populations respond differently to the same tactic
The author themselves later acknowledge or correct a tactic, suggesting it failed to achieve desired effect

intellectual_grounding.method: Following Goffman's analysis of face-work success and failure, this capability examines whether each tactical performance maintains the desired impression or produces embarrassment. It assesses the conditions under which impression management succeeds (audience alignment, smooth execution) versus fails (audience sophistication, clumsy execution, contextual exposure), treating effectiveness as situationally determined rather than absolute.

depth_scaling.deep: Complete taxonomic analysis with fit assessment for every instance (prototypical/borderline/hybrid), documentation of all novel tactics with proposed classifications, analysis of taxonomy coverage and gaps, proposals for category refinements or additions, and reflexive evaluation of whether this author's practice reveals structural limitations in the taxonomy that should be addressed
depth_scaling.standard: Full taxonomy instantiation showing present/absent categories, documentation of any hybrid tactics or boundary cases, and notes on potential extensions or refinements suggested by this author's practice
depth_scaling.surface: List of which taxonomy categories are present versus absent in the author's work

capabilities.description: Map the 10-type taxonomy onto this author's actual behavior, extending with hybrids and novel types as needed
capabilities.extended_description:
This capability maps the engine's ten-type taxonomy onto the author's actual tactical behavior, determining which categories are instantiated, which are absent, and whether the author's practice reveals hybrids, novel tactics, or gaps that suggest taxonomy refinement. The taxonomy is a theoretical framework; instantiation tests it against empirical reality. Some authors use all ten types; others have a narrow repertoire. Some produce clear exemplars of each type; others generate hybrid tactics that combine features (e.g., vocabulary laundering + framework migration executed simultaneously). Following Kuhn's attention to paradigm structure and fit, this capability assesses whether the taxonomy's categories capture what the author actually does or whether they produce recalcitrant cases that resist classification. It also reflexively evaluates whether this author's practice reveals limitations in the taxonomy itself.

This capability depends on tactic_detection for raw instances and tactic_patterns for distribution data. It produces a comprehensive taxonomic map showing which categories are present/absent, how well each category fits (clean exemplars versus forced classifications), and what extensions or refinements the author's behavior suggests. A naive version simply checks boxes for present/absent categories; a sophisticated version assesses quality of fit for each instance (prototypical, borderline, hybrid), documents novel tactics that escape the taxonomy, proposes refined categories or new types when warranted, and reflexively evaluates whether the author's practice reveals that the taxonomy overdraws distinctions (two categories that are actually one) or underdraws them (one category that should be split).
indicators: A detected tactic instance shows features of multiple taxonomy categories simultaneously
An author's behavior seems tactical but doesn't fit cleanly into any of the ten types
Two supposedly distinct tactic types always appear together and may be aspects of one phenomenon
A taxonomy category is never instantiated across dozens of potential instances
Forced classifications where the analyst struggles to justify category assignment

intellectual_grounding.method: Following Kuhn's account of how paradigms are articulated through puzzle-solving that tests and refines exemplars, this capability treats taxonomy instantiation as an empirical test of theoretical categories. It examines how well the ten-type framework accommodates actual tactical behavior, identifying where the taxonomy needs articulation (refinement of boundaries) versus where it encounters genuine anomalies that resist assimilation.

problematique:
When authors write across many years, they inevitably change their
minds. But they rarely just SAY "I changed my mind." Instead, they
employ a repertoire of intellectual self-management tactics --
strategies for handling the relationship between what they said before
and what they say now. These tactics are not necessarily dishonest;
they are often unconscious, sometimes strategic, and always revealing.

This engine detects 10 recurring tactics:

CONCEPTUAL RECYCLING: Reusing old arguments in new frameworks where
they serve different functions -- same building materials, different
building. SILENT REVISION: Changing position without acknowledgment,
writing as if the new view was always held. STRATEGIC ESCALATION:
Promoting tentative prior claims to established facts without new
evidence. FRAMEWORK MIGRATION: Moving concepts between theoretical
homes without justifying the transplant. STRATEGIC AMNESIA:
Selectively forgetting inconvenient prior commitments. VOCABULARY
LAUNDERING: Renaming concepts to shed unwanted associations -- the
same idea reappears under a new name, severed from its problematic
history. AUTHORITY BOOTSTRAPPING: Leveraging credibility earned from
careful prior work to legitimize current speculative claims.
HEDGING RECLASSIFICATION: Retroactively qualifying past claims as
more tentative than they actually were, creating room for the current
position. COMPLEXITY SHIELDING: Burying contradictions between prior
and current positions in layers of complexity so they are difficult
to detect. LEGACY MANAGEMENT: Actively curating one's intellectual
history -- selectively citing earlier work, reframing past positions,
constructing a narrative of purposeful development where the actual
trajectory was more reactive.

The analytical stance is Goffman's: we are watching impression
management applied to intellectual identity. The author is performing
a self that has a coherent intellectual history, and the tactics are
the dramaturgical techniques of that performance. Bourdieu adds the
dimension of cultural capital -- these tactics are strategies for
maintaining and deploying accumulated intellectual credibility.
Kuhn provides the framework for understanding why tactics cluster
around certain moments: paradigm shifts within an author's own work
create the most intense need for self-management.

Every detection must be VERIFIABLE -- grounded in specific vocabulary
evidence, framing evidence, and methodological evidence from both
earlier and later works. The engine does not make impressionistic
judgments; it builds evidence-based cases for each tactic instance.
researcher_question: What tactics does this author use to manage the relationship between their prior and current work?
